speaker: QUINCE
text: Is all our company here?

speaker: BOTTOM
text: You were best to call them generally, man by

speaker: BOTTOM
text: man, according to the scrip.

speaker: QUINCE
text: Here is the scroll of every man’s name which

speaker: QUINCE
text: is thought fit, through all Athens, to play in our

speaker: QUINCE
text: interlude before the Duke and the Duchess on his

speaker: QUINCE
text: wedding day at night.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play

speaker: BOTTOM
text: treats on, then read the names of the actors, and so

speaker: BOTTOM
text: grow to a point.

speaker: QUINCE
text: Marry, our play is “The most lamentable

speaker: QUINCE
text: comedy and most cruel death of Pyramus and

speaker: QUINCE
text: Thisbe.”

speaker: BOTTOM
text: A very good piece of work, I assure you, and a

speaker: BOTTOM
text: merry. Now, good Peter Quince, call forth your

speaker: BOTTOM
text: actors by the scroll. Masters, spread yourselves.

speaker: QUINCE
text: Answer as I call you. Nick Bottom, the weaver.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: Ready. Name what part I am for, and

speaker: BOTTOM
text: proceed.

speaker: QUINCE
text: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: What is Pyramus—a lover or a tyrant?

speaker: QUINCE
text: A lover that kills himself most gallant for love.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: That will ask some tears in the true performing

speaker: BOTTOM
text: of it. If I do it, let the audience look to their

speaker: BOTTOM
text: eyes. I will move storms; I will condole in some

speaker: BOTTOM
text: measure. To the rest.—Yet my chief humor is for a

speaker: BOTTOM
text: tyrant. I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to tear a

speaker: BOTTOM
text: cat in, to make all split:

speaker: BOTTOM
text: This was lofty. Now name the rest of the players.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: This is Ercles’ vein, a tyrant’s vein. A lover is more

speaker: BOTTOM
text: condoling.

speaker: QUINCE
text: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender.

speaker: FLUTE
text: Here, Peter Quince.

speaker: QUINCE
text: Flute, you must take Thisbe on you.

speaker: FLUTE
text: What is Thisbe—a wand’ring knight?

speaker: QUINCE
text: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.

speaker: FLUTE
text: Nay, faith, let not me play a woman. I have a

speaker: FLUTE
text: beard coming.

speaker: QUINCE
text: That’s all one. You shall play it in a mask, and

speaker: QUINCE
text: you may speak as small as you will.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: An I may hide my face, let me play Thisbe too.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: I’ll speak in a monstrous little voice: “Thisne,

speaker: BOTTOM
text: Thisne!”—“Ah Pyramus, my lover dear! Thy Thisbe

speaker: BOTTOM
text: dear and lady dear!”

speaker: QUINCE
text: No, no, you must play Pyramus—and, Flute,

speaker: QUINCE
text: you Thisbe.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: Well, proceed.

speaker: QUINCE
text: Robin Starveling, the tailor.

speaker: STARVELING
text: Here, Peter Quince.

speaker: QUINCE
text: Robin Starveling, you must play Thisbe’s

speaker: QUINCE
text: mother.—Tom Snout, the tinker.

speaker: SNOUT
text: Here, Peter Quince.

speaker: QUINCE
text: You, Pyramus’ father.—Myself, Thisbe’s

speaker: QUINCE
text: father.—Snug the joiner, you the lion’s part.—

speaker: QUINCE
text: And I hope here is a play fitted.

speaker: SNUG
text: Have you the lion’s part written? Pray you, if it

speaker: SNUG
text: be, give it me, for I am slow of study.

speaker: QUINCE
text: You may do it extempore, for it is nothing but

speaker: QUINCE
text: roaring.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: Let me play the lion too. I will roar that I will

speaker: BOTTOM
text: do any man’s heart good to hear me. I will roar that

speaker: BOTTOM
text: I will make the Duke say “Let him roar again. Let

speaker: BOTTOM
text: him roar again!”

speaker: QUINCE
text: An you should do it too terribly, you would

speaker: QUINCE
text: fright the Duchess and the ladies that they would

speaker: QUINCE
text: shriek, and that were enough to hang us all.

speaker: ALL
text: That would hang us, every mother’s son.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: I grant you, friends, if you should fright the

speaker: BOTTOM
text: ladies out of their wits, they would have no more

speaker: BOTTOM
text: discretion but to hang us. But I will aggravate my

speaker: BOTTOM
text: voice so that I will roar you as gently as any sucking

speaker: BOTTOM
text: dove. I will roar you an ’twere any nightingale.

speaker: QUINCE
text: You can play no part but Pyramus, for Pyramus

speaker: QUINCE
text: is a sweet-faced man, a proper man as one

speaker: QUINCE
text: shall see in a summer’s day, a most lovely gentlemanlike

speaker: QUINCE
text: man. Therefore you must needs play

speaker: QUINCE
text: Pyramus.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: Well, I will undertake it. What beard were I

speaker: BOTTOM
text: best to play it in?

speaker: QUINCE
text: Why, what you will.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: I will discharge it in either your straw-color

speaker: BOTTOM
text: beard, your orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain

speaker: BOTTOM
text: beard, or your French-crown-color beard,

speaker: BOTTOM
text: your perfit yellow.

speaker: QUINCE
text: Some of your French crowns have no hair at

speaker: QUINCE
text: all, and then you will play barefaced. But, masters,

speaker: QUINCE
text:
here are your parts,
                 
                giving
                 
                out
                 
                the
                 
                parts
                ,
               and I am

speaker: QUINCE
text: to entreat you, request you, and desire you to con

speaker: QUINCE
text: them by tomorrow night and meet me in the palace

speaker: QUINCE
text: wood, a mile without the town, by moonlight. There

speaker: QUINCE
text: will we rehearse, for if we meet in the city, we shall

speaker: QUINCE
text: be dogged with company and our devices known. In

speaker: QUINCE
text: the meantime I will draw a bill of properties such as

speaker: QUINCE
text: our play wants. I pray you fail me not.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: We will meet, and there we may rehearse

speaker: BOTTOM
text: most obscenely and courageously. Take pains. Be

speaker: BOTTOM
text: perfit. Adieu.

speaker: QUINCE
text: At the Duke’s Oak we meet.

speaker: BOTTOM
text: Enough. Hold or cut bowstrings.
